articles.headline: Israeli Airstrike in Syria Targets Arms Convoy, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Israel carried out a strike deep inside Syria, American officials reported, saying they believed the target was a shipment of antiaircraft weapons meant for Hezbollah in Lebanon.
articles.abstract: Israel carried out a strike deep inside Syria, American officials reported, saying they believed the target was a shipment of antiaircraft weapons meant for Hezbollah in Lebanon.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli warplanes carried out a strike deep inside Syrian territory on Wednesday, American officials reported, saying they believed the target was a convoy carrying sophisticated antiaircraft weaponry on the outskirts of Damascus that was intended for the Hezbollah Shiite militia in Lebanon.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Facebook’s Solid Results Are Greeted Cautiously
articles.snippet: Even with a strong earnings report, the company’s stock dropped after hours before recovering.
articles.abstract: Even with a strong earnings report, the company’s stock dropped after hours before recovering.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook made a lot of money in the last quarter. It also spent a lot. And that made investors once again cautious about the company.

articles.headline: Renewable Energy Industries Push for New Financing Options
articles.snippet: With government approval, investment structures more commonly used by the oil, gas and real estate industries could make wind and solar companies more appealing to investors.
articles.abstract: With government approval, investment structures more commonly used by the oil, gas and real estate industries could make wind and solar companies more appealing to investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, green energy industries like wind and solar have been telling Congress that they cannot yet compete with fossil fuels without hefty tax breaks intended especially for them.

articles.headline: Super Bowl Ad Previews Draw Online Attention, With Criticism
articles.snippet: Versions of Super Bowl ads are already online, in stark contrast to a decades-old strategy of building anticipation by keeping them under wraps until the game.
articles.abstract: Versions of Super Bowl ads are already online, in stark contrast to a decades-old strategy of building anticipation by keeping them under wraps until the game.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don’t misunderstand John Norman, the chief creative officer at TBWA/Chiat/Day Los Angeles. He is excited to be working on a commercial, for Pepsi Next cola, that will appear during Super Bowl XLVII on Sunday — the biggest day of the year for advertising as well as for football.

articles.headline: Making ‘Every Patient Counts’ a Business Imperative
articles.snippet: In the orphan drug market, companies can charge a premium to treat diseases in a small number of people.
articles.abstract: In the orphan drug market, companies can charge a premium to treat diseases in a small number of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Drug companies are fond of saying that every patient counts, but in the world of orphan diseases, entire business plans are built around the idea.

articles.headline: Hackers in China Attacked The Times for Last 4 Months
articles.snippet: The timing of the attacks coincided with reporting for an investigation that found that the relatives of China’s prime minister had accumulated a fortune worth several billion dollars through business dealings.
articles.abstract: The timing of the attacks coincided with reporting for an investigation that found that the relatives of China’s prime minister had accumulated a fortune worth several billion dollars through business dealings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last four months, Chinese hackers have persistently attacked The New York Times, infiltrating its computer systems and getting passwords for its reporters and other employees.

articles.headline: Hagel Has Rough Outing Before Ex-Colleagues
articles.snippet: Chuck Hagel, a Republican former senator and President Obama’s nominee to be secretary of defense, met with sharp questions at his confirmation hearing.
articles.abstract: Chuck Hagel, a Republican former senator and President Obama’s nominee to be secretary of defense, met with sharp questions at his confirmation hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chuck Hagel, President Obama’s nominee to be secretary of defense, faced sharp and sometimes angry questioning from fellow Republicans — especially his old friend Senator John McCain — at a contentious confirmation hearing on Thursday that focused on his past statements on Iran, the influence of pro-Israel organizations in Washington and the Iraq war.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Seeks to Block Anheuser’s Deal for Modelo
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has sued to block Anheuser-Busch InBev’s proposed $20.1 billion deal to buy control of Grupo Modelo of Mexico, the first major roadblock in a decade of consolidation by brewers around the world.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has sued to block Anheuser-Busch InBev’s proposed $20.1 billion deal to buy control of Grupo Modelo of Mexico, the first major roadblock in a decade of consolidation by brewers around the world.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
